articles.headline: Consortium Rescues Bell Canada Takeover
articles.snippet: A private equity and pension fund consortium said it salvaged a record $52 billion deal for Bell Canada on Friday by postponing its closing date and canceling dividend payments.
articles.abstract: A private equity and pension fund consortium said it salvaged a record $52 billion deal for Bell Canada on Friday by postponing its closing date and canceling dividend payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA  A private equity and pension fund consortium said it salvaged a record $52 billion deal for Bell Canada on Friday by postponing its closing date until mid-December and renegotiating some terms of the transaction  including canceling dividend payments on the telecommunication giant’s common stock.

articles.headline: Jesse Helms, Beacon of Conservatism, Dies at 86
articles.snippet: The former senator had a courtly manner and opposed civil rights, gay rights, foreign aid and modern art.
articles.abstract: The former senator had a courtly manner and opposed civil rights, gay rights, foreign aid and modern art.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jesse Helms, the former North Carolina senator with the courtly manner and mossy drawl who turned his hard-edged conservatism against civil rights, gay rights, foreign aid and modern art, died early Friday. He was 86.

articles.headline: Why Fly When You Can Float?
articles.snippet: As the cost of fuel soars and the pressure mounts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, several schemes for a new generation of airship are being considered.
articles.abstract: As the cost of fuel soars and the pressure mounts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, several schemes for a new generation of airship are being considered.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Imagine gliding in a floating hotel over the Serengeti, gazing down at herds of zebra or elephants; or floating over Paris as the sun sets and lights blink on across the city as you pass the Eiffel Tower.

articles.headline: When Credit Gets Tight, a 401(k) Loan Becomes Tempting
articles.snippet: Examining the rationales for supporting or damning the practice of borrowing against a retirement fund can be a useful exercise.
articles.abstract: Examining the rationales for supporting or damning the practice of borrowing against a retirement fund can be a useful exercise.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year, word got out about a Visa debit card aimed at people who wanted to borrow money from their 401(k) accounts. With plastic in hand, they could withdraw the funds from an A.T.M. or spend them at any merchant that accepted Visa, just as they could with a regular bank debit card.

articles.headline: Accounting Plan Would Allow Use of Foreign Rules
articles.snippet: Officials say regulatory changes would attract investment and enhance U.S. competitiveness, but critics say the changes would dilute safeguards.
articles.abstract: Officials say regulatory changes would attract investment and enhance U.S. competitiveness, but critics say the changes would dilute safeguards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Federal officials say they are preparing to propose a series of regulatory changes to enhance American competitiveness overseas, attract foreign investment and give American investors a broader selection of foreign stocks.

articles.headline: Credit Card Overhauls Seem Likely
articles.snippet: Proposed regulations changes are strongly opposed by the credit card industry, which has long beat back any regulatory constraints.
articles.abstract: Proposed regulations changes are strongly opposed by the credit card industry, which has long beat back any regulatory constraints.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumer advocates say regulation of the credit card industry has long been without teeth. But as card holders struggle under the weight of big balances, high interest rates and fees, their pleas to lawmakers for help may well mean that the industry will face some significant regulation by early next year.

articles.headline: Despair Drives Suicide Attacks by Iraqi Women
articles.snippet: In Diyala Province, a trend of bombings by women may be due partly to successes in fighting a terrorist group.
articles.abstract: In Diyala Province, a trend of bombings by women may be due partly to successes in fighting a terrorist group.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq  Wenza Ali Mutlaq walked a bit uncertainly up the long street near the main government offices here on June 22, the hot wind stirring her heavy black abaya. She passed the concrete barricades put up to ward off suicide car bombers and made her way alone, almost haphazardly.

articles.headline: Jesse Helms Dies at 86; Conservative Force in the Senate
articles.snippet: The former North Carolina senator had a courtly manner and mossy drawl and turned his hard-edged conservatism against civil rights, gay rights, foreign aid and modern art.
articles.abstract: The former North Carolina senator had a courtly manner and mossy drawl and turned his hard-edged conservatism against civil rights, gay rights, foreign aid and modern art.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jesse Helms, the former North Carolina senator with the courtly manner and mossy drawl who turned his hard-edged conservatism against civil rights, gay rights, foreign aid and modern art, died early Friday. He was 86.

articles.headline: On Day Care, Google Makes a Rare Fumble
articles.snippet: A battle between employees and their company over in-house day care may be representative of greater changes at Google.
articles.abstract: A battle between employees and their company over in-house day care may be representative of greater changes at Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Google held a series of secret focus groups with employees who have children in Google’s day care facilities. The purpose was to gauge their reaction to the company’s plan to raise the amount it charged for in-house day care by 75 percent.

articles.headline: As Gas Prices Soar, Elderly Face Cuts in Aid
articles.snippet: With fuel costs rising, agencies that provide meals or transportation for senior citizens are struggling.
articles.abstract: With fuel costs rising, agencies that provide meals or transportation for senior citizens are struggling.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH HAVEN, Mich.  Early last month, Jeanne Fair, 62, got her first hot meals delivered to her home in this lake town in the sparsely populated southwestern part of the state. Then after two deliveries the meals stopped because gas prices had made the delivery too expensive.

articles.headline: Merrill Said to Be in Talks to Sell Bloomberg Stake
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch, seeking capital, may sell its 20 percent stake in the financial data company, people involved said.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch, seeking capital, may sell its 20 percent stake in the financial data company, people involved said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch is in negotiations to sell its 20 percent stake in Bloomberg L.P., the financial data and news company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, as the firm seeks to raise still more capital, people involved in the talks said Friday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: McCain Battles a Nemesis, the Teleprompter
articles.snippet: A politician who thrives in informal settings is trying to meet the more scripted speaking demands of a general election campaign.
articles.abstract: A politician who thrives in informal settings is trying to meet the more scripted speaking demands of a general election campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS Senator John McCain was performing relatively smoothly as he unveiled his energy plan.

articles.headline: At $100 for Tank of Gas, Some Choke on ‘Fill It’
articles.snippet: Owners of large vehicles have hit an uncomfortable price milestone and are cutting back on recreational driving.
articles.abstract: Owners of large vehicles have hit an uncomfortable price milestone and are cutting back on recreational driving.
articles.lead_paragraph: With gasoline prices high and rising, a new financial milestone has arrived: the $100 tank of gas.

articles.headline: Ancient Tablet Ignites Debate on Messiah and Resurrection
articles.snippet: The writing on an ancient stone may contribute to a re-evaluation of popular and scholarly views of Jesus.
articles.abstract: The writing on an ancient stone may contribute to a re-evaluation of popular and scholarly views of Jesus.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  A three-foot-tall tablet with 87 lines of Hebrew that scholars believe dates from the decades just before the birth of Jesus is causing a quiet stir in biblical and archaeological circles, especially because it may speak of a messiah who will rise from the dead after three days.

articles.headline: Cashing In on Obama and McCain
articles.snippet: Nearly half of the $900 million the presidential candidates have spent on their campaigns has been paid to just a few dozen companies.
articles.abstract: Nearly half of the $900 million the presidential candidates have spent on their campaigns has been paid to just a few dozen companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHN McCAIN and Barack Obama are not the only winners to emerge from the long presidential primary season.
articles.byline: By Hannah Fairfield and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: Employers Fight Tough Measures on Immigration
articles.snippet: Businesses are proposing alternatives to laws with harsh punishments for hiring illegal immigrants, reopening a rift in the Republican Party.
articles.abstract: Businesses are proposing alternatives to laws with harsh punishments for hiring illegal immigrants, reopening a rift in the Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from the toughest crackdown on illegal immigration in two decades, employers across the country are fighting back in state legislatures, the federal courts and city halls.

articles.headline: American Energy Policy, Asleep at the Spigot
articles.snippet: Americans have seen the current oil crisis coming for 30 years. But analysts say chances to head it off were ignored, missed or blocked.
articles.abstract: Americans have seen the current oil crisis coming for 30 years. But analysts say chances to head it off were ignored, missed or blocked.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST three years ago, with oil trading at a seemingly frothy $66 a barrel, David J. O’Reilly made what many experts considered a risky bet. Outmaneuvering Chinese bidders and ignoring critics who said he overpaid, Mr. O’Reilly, the chief executive of Chevron, forked over $18 billion to buy Unocal, a giant whose riches date back to oil fields made famous in the film “There Will Be Blood.”

articles.headline: A Window in a Smoky Market
articles.snippet: The market for credit default swaps, one of the hottest and also one of the foggiest, might just get a bit clearer if a new accounting rule goes into effect.
articles.abstract: The market for credit default swaps, one of the hottest and also one of the foggiest, might just get a bit clearer if a new accounting rule goes into effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERYBODY knows that the market for credit default swaps is one of the hottest investment arenas around. At the end of last year, according to the Bank for International Settlements, the fair value of credit default swaps outstanding totaled $2 trillion, up from “just” $133 billion three years earlier.

articles.headline: As Web Traffic Grows, Crashes Take Bigger Toll
articles.snippet: As the Web has become an integral part of life, users have become less forgiving of even occasional outages.
articles.abstract: As the Web has become an integral part of life, users have become less forgiving of even occasional outages.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Alex Payne, a 24-year-old Internet engineer here, has devised a way to answer a commonly asked question of the digital age: Is my favorite Web site working today?

articles.headline: It’s American Brandstand: Marketers Underwrite Performers
articles.snippet: Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods giant, is part of a wave of companies getting into the music business to promote their own products.
articles.abstract: Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods giant, is part of a wave of companies getting into the music business to promote their own products.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hip-hop and R&B producer Jermaine Dupri has discovered best-selling acts like Kris Kross and Da Brat, has produced hits for Mariah Carey and Jay-Z, and now runs the urban music division of the Island Def Jam Music Group. He’s also looking for fresh talent for a new label financed by a company new to the music industry.

articles.headline: Google, Zen Master of the Market
articles.snippet: Microsoft challenged the rules on competition and antitrust law. Now, it’s Google’s turn.
articles.abstract: Microsoft challenged the rules on competition and antitrust law. Now, it’s Google’s turn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, who walked away from full-time work at Microsoft last month, was perhaps the foremost applied economist of the second half of the 20th century.

articles.headline: Obama’s Organizing Years, Guiding Others and Finding Himself
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s years as a grass-roots organizer have figured prominently, if not profoundly, in his narrative.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s years as a grass-roots organizer have figured prominently, if not profoundly, in his narrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  The year was 1985 and Gerald Kellman, a community organizer, was interviewing an applicant named Barack Obama to work in the demoralized landscape of poor neighborhoods on this city’s South Side. He liked the young man’s intelligence, motivation and acutely personal understanding of how it felt to be an outsider. He also remembers that Mr. Obama drove a hard bargain.

articles.headline: Decades Later, Toxic Sludge Torments Bhopal
articles.snippet: Hundreds of tons of waste still languish on the grounds of a pesticide factory in India, the site of a notorious disaster.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of tons of waste still languish on the grounds of a pesticide factory in India, the site of a notorious disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: BHOPAL, India — Hundreds of tons of waste still languish inside a tin-roofed warehouse in a corner of the old grounds of the Union Carbide pesticide factory here, nearly a quarter-century after a poison gas leak killed thousands and turned this ancient city into a notorious symbol of industrial disaster.

articles.headline: Quietly, Brazil Eclipses an Ally
articles.snippet: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil has pulled away from Venezuela while nurturing a regional power.
articles.abstract: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil has pulled away from Venezuela while nurturing a regional power.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela and President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil clasped hands here at a summit meeting late last month, as employees of Venezuela’s state oil company raised their fists and shouted Cuban-inspired socialist slogans before the cameras.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: The Facebooker Who Friended Obama
articles.snippet: When a Clinton strategist said Barack Obama’s supporters “look like Facebook,” Chris Hughes took it as a compliment.
articles.abstract: When a Clinton strategist said Barack Obama’s supporters “look like Facebook,” Chris Hughes took it as a compliment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last November, Mark Penn, then the chief strategist for Hillary Rodham Clinton, derisively said Barack Obama’s supporters “look like Facebook.”

articles.headline: When Fox News Is the Story
articles.snippet: At Fox News, media relations is a kind of rolling opposition research operation intended to keep reporters in line.
articles.abstract: At Fox News, media relations is a kind of rolling opposition research operation intended to keep reporters in line.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like most working journalists, whenever I type seven letters  Fox News  a series of alarms begins to whoop in my head: Danger. Warning. Much mayhem ahead.
